definitions.definition: a person who is being taught, especially a child in a school
definitions.labels: (especially British English, becoming old-fashioned)(British English)British English

examples.text: How many pupils does the school have?
She now teaches only private pupils.
Daniel is the star pupil at school.
Ex-pupils try to have a reunion every five years.
Pupils at Meadow School have raised £1 500 for charity.
What measures can we take to deal with disruptive pupils?
We expect pupil numbers to increase next year.

definitions.definition: a person who is taught artistic, musical, etc. skills by an expert

examples.text: Charpentier took pupils and taught them composition and accompanying.
The painting is by a pupil of Rembrandt.

definitions.definition: the small round black area at the centre of the eye

wordOrigin: senses 1 to 2 late Middle English (in the sense ‘orphan, ward’): from Old French pupille, from Latin pupillus (diminutive of pupus ‘boy’) and pupilla (diminutive of pupa ‘girl’).sense 3 late Middle English: from Old French pupille or Latin pupilla, diminutive of pupa ‘doll’ (so named from the tiny reflected images visible in the eye).
